The situation is radically different for magnetic fields which are continuous and form closed loops. Examine the Gaussian surfaces represented by ① or ① in Fig 5.2(a) or Fig. 5.2(b). Both cases visually demonstrate that the number of magnetic field lines leaving the surface is balanced by the number of lines entering it. The net magnetic flux is zero for both the surfaces. This is true for any closed surface.

![img-8.jpeg](images/image_6_8.jpeg)

summary: Explains that magnetic fields are continuous and form closed loops. Discussed cases of Gaussian surfaces, wherein the net magnetic flux is zero, for the situations represented by ① in Figs 5.2(a) and 5.2(b). Mentioned that the net magnetic flux is zero for any closed surface.
hypothetical_questions: What properties do magnetic fields have that are different from electric fields?
How is the net magnetic flux determined for a closed surface?
Can you provide an example of magnetic field lines forming closed loops?
